awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Bioinformatics Research and Interdisciplinary Training Experience in Analysis and Interpretation of Information-Rich Biological Data Sets (REU-BRITE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Boston University, located in Boston, MA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020- 2022. It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities or from an under-represented group, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. The program will help train a diverse group of future bioinformatics scientists, who understand and can easily manipulate a wide range of computational, mathematical, and statistical techniques to analyze and model the very large data sets produced by contemporary biological experiments. Research outcomes from the program are expected to create new knowledge-based resources for biological research. Assessment of the program will be done through the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.

The program will focus on computational and mathematical analyses of biological data. Students will conduct full-time research with a Boston University Bioinformatics faculty mentor in one of a broad range of biological research fields, including the microbiome in humans and the environment, the linkage between genetic variation and phenotype, gene regulatory networks, biomolecular interactions, and ecological forecasting. Students will learn how to analyze high-throughput data, gain experience in statistical and machine learning methods, and assist with the development of computational tools and methodologies. Components will include: 1) workshops on bioinformatics computing, 2) workshops on creating a scientific abstract and poster, 3) poster presentation at an undergraduate research conference, 4) educational outreach to community elementary and middle school students, 5) scientific enrichment and career networking at Boston University Bioinformatics sponsored symposia, 6) training in preparing a competitive graduate school application, 7) training in scientific ethics, and 8) cultural and social enrichment in the Boston area. Participants will be selected by the Principal Investigator and potential faculty mentors after completion of an online application. More information about the program is available by visiting http://sites.bu.edu/britereu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Gary Benson at gbenson@bu.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Boston University (BU) Bioinformatics Research and Interdisciplinary Training Experience - Research Experience for Undergraduates Program (BRITE - REU) operated for three summers, 2021-2023. The program was cancelled for one summer (2020) during the first wave of the covid-19 pandemic, was resumed the next summer (2021), but was held entirely remotely, and then held fully in person again in summers 2022 and 2023. The program trained a total of 32 undergraduate rising juniors and seniors (62% women, 37% underrepresented minorities, 34% first generation college students, 47% from institutions with limited research opportunities, and collectively 97% in one of these categories).  The students conducted interdisciplinary computational research for 10 weeks in the labs of faculty members of the BU Bioinformatics Graduate Program.  The research, using mathematical and computational tools, spanned a variety of biomedical and ecological topic areas, including cell type classification using gene expression data; human genetic variation detection; skeletal development modeling; microbiome studies; gene regulation modeling; identification of gene expression differences and mutational differences in disease (Alzheimer's disease, cervical cancer, leukemia); detection of cell type co-localization during organism development; detection of RNA binding protein localization in cells; protein-protein interaction modeling; ecological modeling of coral and mangroves; and ecological forecasting of the carbon cycle. Learning activities included 1) seven workshops on computer programming languages and tools frequently used in bioinformatics, 2) instruction on creating a scientific poster and giving a scientific talk, 3) scientific symposia and bioinformatics research talks, 4) training in research ethics and laboratory safety, 5) workshops on applying to graduate school, and professional development, and 6) networking opportunities. A variety of social and cultural activities introduced the students to many unique aspects of Boston. Eighteen faculty members, 25 graduate students, and 2 postdocs mentored the undergraduates.  Surveys during and after the summer activities were used to evaluate the effectiveness of the program and student satisfaction with the activities.  Students reported great gains in their ability to do research and contribute to science.  At the end of each summer all students gave a short talk on their research at a mini-symposium held at BU.  They also each submitted a poster abstract to the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), a top national undergraduate research conference.  Nearly all students (97%) gave poster presentations at ABRCMS and 7 students (22%) earned ABRCMS Poster Presentation awards.  Three students were honored with travel awards from the ABRCMS organization to defray costs of conference attendance and two others received travel awards from the National Science Foundation, BIO REU travel awards program.
